hints.label: def-emergent-manifold-fixed
hints.title: Emergent Manifold at Fixed Swarm State
hints.content:
556: :label: def-emergent-manifold-fixed
557: 
558: For a fixed swarm configuration $S = \{(x_i, v_i, s_i)\}$, the **emergent manifold** at walker $i$ is the Riemannian manifold:
559: 
560: $$
561: (\mathcal{X}, g_i(x)) := (\mathcal{X}, H_i(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I)
562: 
563: $$
564: 
565: where $x \in \mathcal{X}$ is the position variable and $S$ is held fixed.
566: 
567: The metric defines:
568: - **Geodesic distance**: The length-minimizing curves in $(\mathcal{X}, g_i)$
hints.raw_directive:
553: The adaptive diffusion tensor $D_{\text{reg}}(x, S) = (H(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1}$ defines a **state-dependent Riemannian manifold**.
554: 
555: :::{prf:definition} Emergent Manifold at Fixed Swarm State
556: :label: def-emergent-manifold-fixed

559:

561: (\mathcal{X}, g_i(x)) := (\mathcal{X}, H_i(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I)
562: 
563: $$
564: 
565: where $x \in \mathcal{X}$ is the position variable and $S$ is held fixed.
566: 
567: The metric defines:
568: - **Geodesic distance**: The length-minimizing curves in $(\mathcal{X}, g_i)$
569: - **Volume form**: $dV_g = \sqrt{\det g_i(x)} \, dx$

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-23
hints.title: Time-Dependent Manifold
hints.content:
574: :class: note
575: 
576: As the swarm evolves, $S_t$ changes, hence the metric $g(x, S_t)$ evolves in time. The emergent manifold is **time-dependent**: the geometry adapts to the current swarm configuration.

hints.label: thm-emergent-isometries
hints.title: Emergent Isometries for Euclidean Transformations
hints.content:
584: :label: thm-emergent-isometries
585: 
586: Suppose the fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S)$ is invariant under a **Euclidean isometry** $\Phi: \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{X}$ (i.e., an affine transformation preserving the Euclidean metric: translations, rotations, reflections):
587: 
588: $$
589: V_{\text{fit}}(\Phi(x), \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S)) = V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S)
590: 
591: $$
592: 
593: where:
594: - $\Phi(x) = Lx + b$ with $L \in O(d)$ (orthogonal matrix) and $b \in \mathbb{R}^d$
595: - $\Phi_L(v) = Lv$ (velocity transforms with the linear part)
596: - $\Phi_*(S) = \{(\Phi(x_i), \Phi_L(v_i), s_i)\}$ is the push-forward of the swarm
597: 
598: Then $\Phi$ is an **isometry** of the emergent metric:
599: 
600: $$
601: \Phi^* g(x, S) = g(\Phi(x), \Phi_*(S))
602: 
603: $$
hints.raw_directive:
581: ### 3.2. Riemannian Isometries
582: 
583: :::{prf:theorem} Emergent Isometries for Euclidean Transformations
584: :label: thm-emergent-isometries
585: 
586: Suppose the fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S)$ is invariant under a **Euclidean isometry** $\Phi: \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{X}$ (i.e., an affine transformation preserving the Euclidean metric: translations, rotations, reflections):
587: 
588: $$
589: V_{\text{fit}}(\Phi(x), \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S)) = V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S)
590: 
591: $$
592: 
593: where:
594: - $\Phi(x) = Lx + b$ with $L \in O(d)$ (orthogonal matrix) and $b \in \mathbb{R}^d$
595: - $\Phi_L(v) = Lv$ (velocity transforms with the linear part)
596: - $\Phi_*(S) = \{(\Phi(x_i), \Phi_L(v_i), s_i)\}$ is the push-forward of the swarm
597: 
598: Then $\Phi$ is an **isometry** of the emergent metric:
599: 
600: $$
601: \Phi^* g(x, S) = g(\Phi(x), \Phi_*(S))
602: 
603: $$
604:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-58
hints.content:
607: 
608: :::{prf:proof}
609: We prove that Euclidean isometries preserving the fitness potential are also isometries of the emergent metric.
610: 
611: **Step 1: Jacobian of Euclidean isometry**
612: 
613: For $\Phi(x) = Lx + b$ with $L \in O(d)$ (orthogonal), the Jacobian is constant:
614: 
615: $$
616: D\Phi(x) = L
617: 
618: $$
619: 
620: Since $L$ is orthogonal: $L^T L = I$.
621: 
622: **Step 2: Transformation of Hessian**
623: 
624: The emergent metric is:
625: 
626: $$
627: g(x, S) = \nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I
628: 
629: $$
630: 
631: For a function $V: \mathbb{R}^d \to \mathbb{R}$, the Hessian transforms under an affine map $\Phi(x) = Lx + b$ as:
632: 
633: $$
634: \nabla^2_x V(\Phi(x)) = L^T [\nabla^2_y V(y)]_{y=Lx+b} L
635: 
636: $$
637: 
638: where the gradient and Hessian on the right are with respect to the $y$ variable.
639: 
640: **Step 3: Invariance condition**
641: 
642: By assumption, $V_{\text{fit}}(\Phi(x), \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S)) = V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S)$.
643: 
644: Define $\tilde{V}(x) = V_{\text{fit}}(\Phi(x), \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S))$. Then:
645: 
646: $$
647: \nabla^2_x \tilde{V}(x) = L^T \nabla^2_y V_{\text{fit}}(y, \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S))\Big|_{y=Lx+b} L
648: 
649: $$
650: 
651: But by invariance, $\tilde{V}(x) = V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S)$, so:
652: 
653: $$
654: \nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S) = L^T \nabla^2_y V_{\text{fit}}(y, \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S))\Big|_{y=Lx+b} L
655: 
656: $$
657: 
658: Setting $y = Lx + b = \Phi(x)$:
659: 
660: $$
661: \nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S) = L^T \nabla^2_{\Phi(x)} V_{\text{fit}}(\Phi(x), \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S)) L
662: 
663: $$
664: 
665: **Step 4: Pull-back of metric**
666: 
667: The pull-back of the metric tensor by $\Phi$ is:
668: 
669: $$
670: (\Phi^* g)(\Phi(x), \Phi_*(S)) = L^T g(\Phi(x), \Phi_*(S)) L
671: 
672: $$
673: 
674: Using the result from Step 3:
675: 
676: $$
677: (\Phi^* g)(\Phi(x), \Phi_*(S)) = L^T [\nabla^2 V(\Phi(x), \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S)) + \epsilon_\Sigma I] L
678: 
679: $$
680: 
681: $$
682: = L^T \nabla^2 V(\Phi(x), \Phi_L(v), \Phi_*(S)) L + \epsilon_\Sigma L^T L
683: 
684: $$
685: 
686: $$
687: = \nabla^2 V(x, v, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \quad \text{(by invariance and } L^T L = I \text{)}
688: 
689: $$
690: 
691: $$
692: = g(x, S)
693: 
694: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-149
hints.title: Extension to General Diffeomorphisms
hints.content:
700: :class: note
701: 
702: **Open question**: Can this theorem be extended to **general diffeomorphisms** beyond Euclidean isometries?
703: 
704: For a general smooth map $\Phi$, the condition $(D\Phi)^T D\Phi = I$ does not hold. The Hessian transformation becomes:
705: 
706: $$
707: \nabla^2 V(\Phi(x)) = L^T \nabla^2 V(y)|_{y=\Phi(x)} L + \text{(second-order correction terms)}
708: 
709: $$
710: 
711: involving second derivatives of $\Phi$ (the Christoffel symbols of the transformation).
712: 
713: A sufficient condition for $\Phi$ to be an isometry would be:
714: 1. $V(\Phi(x), \Phi_*(S)) = V(x, S)$ (fitness invariance)
715: 2. $D\Phi$ preserves the metric: $(D\Phi)^T D\Phi = g^{-1}$ (conformal condition)

hints.title: Radial Symmetry Induces Spherical Geometry
hints.content:
721: :class: tip
722: 
723: For a radially symmetric fitness $V_{\text{fit}}(x, v, S) = f(\|x\|, v, S)$, the emergent metric is also radially symmetric:

727: 
728: $$
729: 
730: where $g_r$ and $g_\perp$ are the radial and tangential components.

hints.label: thm-geodesic-invariance
hints.title: Geodesic Invariance Under Isometries
hints.content:
738: :label: thm-geodesic-invariance
739: 
740: Let $\Phi: \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{X}$ be an isometry of the emergent metric $g(x, S)$ (as in Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-emergent-isometries`). If $\gamma(t)$ is a geodesic of $(\mathcal{X}, g(\cdot, S))$, then $\Phi(\gamma(t))$ is also a geodesic.
741: 
742: Furthermore, the **geodesic length** is preserved:
743: 
744: $$
745: L_g(\Phi(\gamma)) = L_g(\gamma)
746: 
747: $$
hints.raw_directive:
735: ### 3.3. Geodesic Preservation
736: 
737: :::{prf:theorem} Geodesic Invariance Under Isometries
738: :label: thm-geodesic-invariance
739: 
740: Let $\Phi: \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{X}$ be an isometry of the emergent metric $g(x, S)$ (as in Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-emergent-isometries`). If $\gamma(t)$ is a geodesic of $(\mathcal{X}, g(\cdot, S))$, then $\Phi(\gamma(t))$ is also a geodesic.
741: 
742: Furthermore, the **geodesic length** is preserved:
743: 
744: $$
745: L_g(\Phi(\gamma)) = L_g(\gamma)
746: 
747: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-202
hints.content:
751: 
752: :::{prf:proof}
753: **Geodesic equation**: A curve $\gamma(t)$ is a geodesic if it satisfies:
754: 
755: $$
756: \nabla_{\dot{\gamma}} \dot{\gamma} = 0
757: 
758: $$
759: 
760: where $\nabla$ is the Levi-Civita connection of $g$.
761: 
762: **Isometry property**: Since $\Phi^* g = g$, the connection transforms as:
763: 
764: $$
765: \Phi^* \nabla = \nabla
766: 
767: $$
768: 
769: Therefore:
770: 
771: $$
772: \nabla_{d\Phi(\dot{\gamma})} d\Phi(\dot{\gamma}) = d\Phi(\nabla_{\dot{\gamma}} \dot{\gamma}) = 0
773: 
774: $$
775: 
776: Hence $\Phi(\gamma)$ is a geodesic.
777: 
778: **Length preservation**: The metric tensor pulls back as $\Phi^* g = g$, so:
779: 
780: $$
781: g(\Phi(\gamma(t)))(d\Phi(\dot{\gamma}(t)), d\Phi(\dot{\gamma}(t))) = (\Phi^* g)(\gamma(t))(\dot{\gamma}(t), \dot{\gamma}(t)) = g(\gamma(t))(\dot{\gamma}(t), \dot{\gamma}(t))
782: 
783: $$

hints.label: def-emergent-curvature
hints.title: Emergent Riemann Curvature
hints.content:
806: :label: def-emergent-curvature
807: 
808: The **Riemann curvature tensor** of $(\mathcal{X}, g(x, S))$ is:
809: 
810: $$
811: R(X, Y)Z = \nabla_X \nabla_Y Z - \nabla_Y \nabla_X Z - \nabla_{[X,Y]} Z
812: 
813: $$
814: 
815: The **sectional curvature** in the 2-plane spanned by orthonormal vectors $u, v$ is:
816: 
817: $$
818: K(u, v) = \frac{g(R(u, v)v, u)}{g(u, u) g(v, v) - g(u, v)^2}
hints.raw_directive:
803: The **Riemann curvature tensor** of the emergent manifold encodes higher-order geometric information.
804:

806: :label: def-emergent-curvature
807: 
808: The **Riemann curvature tensor** of $(\mathcal{X}, g(x, S))$ is:
809: 
810: $$
811: R(X, Y)Z = \nabla_X \nabla_Y Z - \nabla_Y \nabla_X Z - \nabla_{[X,Y]} Z
812: 
813: $$
814: 
815: The **sectional curvature** in the 2-plane spanned by orthonormal vectors $u, v$ is:
816: 
817: $$
818: K(u, v) = \frac{g(R(u, v)v, u)}{g(u, u) g(v, v) - g(u, v)^2}

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-306
hints.title: Physical Interpretation: Ricci Flow Analogy
hints.content:
857: :class: important
858: 
859: The Ricci curvature governs the **volume growth rate** of geodesic balls. High Ricci curvature indicates regions where the manifold is "pinching" (volume grows slowly), while low/negative curvature indicates "spreading" (volume grows rapidly).
860: 
861: In the Adaptive Gas:
862: - **High curvature** (high fitness Hessian) → Small diffusion → Exploitation
863: - **Low curvature** (flat fitness landscape) → Large diffusion → Exploration

hints.label: thm-fisher-geometry
hints.title: Fisher-Rao Geometry Embedding
hints.content:
873: :label: thm-fisher-geometry
874: 
875: Suppose the fitness potential arises from a **statistical model** $p_\theta(r)$ with parameter $\theta = x \in \mathcal{X}$. Define:
876: 
877: $$
878: V_{\text{fit}}(x) = -\log p_x(r_{\text{obs}})
879: 
880: $$
881: 
882: where $r_{\text{obs}}$ is an observed reward.
883: 
884: Then the Hessian $H(x) = \nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}(x)$ is the **Fisher information matrix**:
885: 
886: $$
887: H_{ij}(x) = \mathbb{E}_{r \sim p_x}\left[\frac{\partial \log p_x(r)}{\partial x_i} \frac{\partial \log p_x(r)}{\partial x_j}\right]
888: 
889: $$
hints.raw_directive:
870: The emergent metric has a natural interpretation in **information geometry**.
871: 
872: :::{prf:theorem} Fisher-Rao Geometry Embedding
873: :label: thm-fisher-geometry
874: 
875: Suppose the fitness potential arises from a **statistical model** $p_\theta(r)$ with parameter $\theta = x \in \mathcal{X}$. Define:
876: 
877: $$
878: V_{\text{fit}}(x) = -\log p_x(r_{\text{obs}})
879: 
880: $$
881: 
882: where $r_{\text{obs}}$ is an observed reward.
883: 
884: Then the Hessian $H(x) = \nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}(x)$ is the **Fisher information matrix**:
885: 
886: $$
887: H_{ij}(x) = \mathbb{E}_{r \sim p_x}\left[\frac{\partial \log p_x(r)}{\partial x_i} \frac{\partial \log p_x(r)}{\partial x_j}\right]
888: 
889: $$
890:

895: **Fisher information definition**: For a parametric family $p_\theta$, the Fisher information is:
896: 
897: $$
898: I_{ij}(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_{x \sim p_\theta}\left[\frac{\partial \log p_\theta(x)}{\partial \theta_i} \frac{\partial \log p_\theta(x)}{\partial \theta_j}\right]
899: 
900: $$
901: 
902: **Negative log-likelihood**: If $V(\theta) = -\log p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}})$, then:
903: 
904: $$
905: \nabla V(\theta) = -\frac{\nabla p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}})}{p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}})}
906: 
907: $$
908: 
909: The Hessian is:
910: 
911: $$
912: \nabla^2 V(\theta) = -\frac{\nabla^2 p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}})}{p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}})} + \frac{(\nabla p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}}))(\nabla p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}}))^T}{p_\theta(x_{\text{obs}})^2}
913: 
914: $$
915: 
916: Taking expectation over $x_{\text{obs}} \sim p_\theta$ and using $\mathbb{E}[\nabla^2 \log p] = -I$ (for regular families), recovers the Fisher information.
917: 
918: **Natural gradient**: The natural gradient is defined as:
919: 
920: $$
921: \nabla_{\text{nat}} V = I^{-1} \nabla V
922: 
923: $$
924: 
925: The regularized metric $g = I + \epsilon_\Sigma I$ gives:
926: 
927: $$
928: \nabla_{\text{nat}} V \approx (I + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1} \nabla V
929: 
930: $$
